3. Select List Prices from Microsoft Excel

entry.title: Re: List Prices from Microsoft Excel Not Working As Expected
entry.content:
Hello,

This is the correct behavior for List Prices, the button will always download a fresh template so you can edit and then send it back to the system. To be able to add a new List Price on system using Microsoft Excel is necessary to install the Add-In for Microsoft Excel, and then upload using the Save data to button. For this you can follow the below steps:

Firstly, install the SAP Add-In for Microsoft Excel by following the below steps:

Go to the Application and User Management work center.
Enter the Download Center view.
Click on the download icon for SAP Add-In for Microsoft Excel.
After the download, execute the installer on your machine.
Once the installation is successfully completed, a new tab SAP BUSINESS BYDESIGN will be available in the excel workbook. 

Follow the below steps to Import List Prices via Excel:

Open the Microsoft Excel workbook.
Go to the tab SAP BUSINESS BYDESIGN and log into the desired system using the Logon option available. Enter the tenant URL, Username and password to login. 
Go to Product Portfolio work center and navigate to List prices view.
Click on New and choose the option List prices from Microsoft Excel. 
This will download the template for importing the List prices in the Excel. 
Open the downloaded template in Microsoft Excel.
Enter all the relevant details.
Go to SAP BUSINESS BYDESIGN tab and click on the option Save data to. 
This will successfully import the List prices data into the system. 
Navigate to UI to check the List price details. 
Hope this clarifies your questions.

In case you have any further questions or issues, please reach out to me and I'll be glad to help.â€¨Otherwise please complete the incident and reply to our SAP Support Satisfaction Survey and share with me what you enjoyed the most about the experience you had with my work.â€¨
Once you complete the incident, you will be redirected to the survey and this will help me to always deliver a great support.â€¨

Thanks,â€¨
DiÃ©ssicaâ€¨
SAP Supportâ€¨

entry.title: Re: calculating depreciatio in SAP SAC Advance formula
entry.content: Can you try below once :

entry.title: Re: calculating depreciatio in SAP SAC Advance formula
entry.content: try below once :

entry.title: Re: calculating depreciatio in SAP SAC Advance formula
entry.content:
Try as below 

// Limit to the 2-year budget horizon
MEMBERSET [d/Time] = [d/Time].[2025.JAN:2026.DEC]

// Loop over each Asset
FOREACH [d/Asset]

  // Get values from measures
  DATA(cost)       = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures].[AssetCost]);
  DATA(lifeYears)  = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures].[UsefulLife]);   // years
  DATA(endDateIdx) = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures].[EndDateIdx]);   // YYYYMM number

  // Skip if no cost or no life
  IF (cost = 0 OR lifeYears = 0)
    CONTINUE;
  ENDIF;

  // Convert useful life in years â†’ months
  DATA(lifeMonths) = lifeYears * 12;

  // First month of depreciation = asset end date + 1
  DATA(depStart) = endDateIdx + 1;

  // Last month by useful life
  DATA(depEndByLife) = depStart + lifeMonths - 1;

  // Last month allowed by budget (Dec 2026 = 202612)
  DATA(budgetEnd) = 202612;

  // Take the earlier of life end vs budget end
  DATA(depEnd) = depEndByLife;
  IF (depEnd > budgetEnd)
    depEnd = budgetEnd;
  ENDIF;

  // Monthly depreciation amount
  DATA(monthDep) = cost / lifeMonths;

  // Now loop through time periods and post depreciation
  FOREACH [d/Time]
    // Read the MonthIndex of this time period
    DATA(curIdx) = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures].[MonthIndex]);

    // Post depreciation only if within range
    IF (curIdx >= depStart AND curIdx <= depEnd)
      RESULT([d/Measures].[Depreciation]) = monthDep;
    ENDIF;

  ENDFOR;

ENDFOR;

entry.title: Discrepancy for PDT & GR Processing time between Procurement proposals
entry.content:
During the MRP run, the system considered the Planned Delivery Time and GR Processing Time from the contract and created planned orders, as the dates were not within the opening period. However, the PDT and GR Processing Time fields displayed are from the material master. In the opening period, when the program RMCVPLRQ ran to convert planned orders to purchase requisitions, it uses the values from the planned order, which were originally taken from the material master. As a result, the purchase requisitions are created using the values from the material master, not from the contract.

Parameters used:

  • Create Purchase Requisition: 2
  • SA Delivery Schedule Lines: 1
  • Create MRP List: 2
  • Planning Mode: 1
  • Scheduling: 1

How to tackle this kind of issue?

entry.title: Deployed CAP+Fiori App is running, but UI gives 404 on metadata call and is not visible in Work Zone
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I'm developing a full-stack application in SAP Business Application Studio and I'm facing a final issue after a seemingly successful deployment to Cloud Foundry.

My Project Setup:

  • Backend: SAP CAP with Node.js

  • Database: SAP HANA Cloud, using synonyms to access tables from another container.

  • Frontend: SAP Fiori Elements (List Report Object Page template).

  • Security: Using a standard XSUAA service.

  • Deployment Target: The final goal is to integrate the app into our SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition.

The Problem / Observed Behavior: The deployment to Cloud Foundry using cf deploy completes 100% successfully. In the CF space, I can see that my applications (-srv, -ui) are in the "Started" state, and the -db-deployer is "Stopped", which is the expected behavior.

The issue is that the application is unreachable and invisible to end-users:

  1. When I access the direct URL of the CAP backend service (...-srv.cfapps...), I correctly see the CAP welcome page listing my service endpoint at /odata/v4/catalog. This confirms the backend is alive and serving the correct path.

  2. However, when I access the main UI application URL (...-ui.cfapps...), the page title loads, but the rest of the page is blank.

  3. Checking the browser's developer console, I see a 404 (Not Found) error when the application tries to fetch the service metadata. The failing request is: GET .../odata/v4/catalog/$metadata.

  4. Consequently, the application does not appear in the Content Explorer of the SAP Build Work Zone after refreshing the "HTML5 Apps" content provider.

My Question: What could be the reason for the 404 Not Found error during the metadata call from the UI, given that the deployment is successful and the backend service is confirmed to be running and serving the correct path? It seems there is a routing or communication issue between the AppRouter (-ui app) and the CAP service (-srv app) that I am unable to diagnose further.

Relevant Configuration Files attached

entry.title: Re: which products are linked to the SAP RISE license (cl...
entry.content:
Hello @davi3 

RISE with SAP is sold as a subscription bundle, so the license covers more than just the S/4HANA system. The exact components depend on whether youâ€™re using SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition or Private Edition, but in both cases, you get a package of core products and services:

SAP S/4HANA Core

  • Public Edition â†’ SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (multi-tenant SaaS) with scope items delivered as standard.
  • Private Edition â†’ SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (single-tenant) based on the full S/4HANA stack, offering greater flexibility for custom code and extensions.

Infrastructure and Technical Services

  • Included hyperscaler infrastructure (AWS, Azure, GCP, or SAP DC).
  • Technical managed services (system provisioning, upgrades, patching, monitoring).

Business Process Intelligence

  • SAP Signavio Process Transformation Suite (process discovery, benchmarking, modelling, and mining).

SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP)

  • Credits for extensions, integrations, and analytics (typically a starter package included with Cloud Platform Enterprise Agreement consumption)
  • Preconfigured integration content (SAP Integration Suite) and extensibility options.

Tools for Migration and Activation

  • SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit and readiness check.
  • SAP Activate methodology, accelerators, and best practices.

Embedded Support & Operations

  • SAP Cloud ALM (Application Lifecycle Management).
  • SAP Enterprise Support, Cloud Edition.
  • SAP Readiness Check, maintenance, and security services.

Key Differences

  • Public Edition â†’ SaaS model, standardised scope, quarterly releases, limited customisation.
  • Private Edition includes the full ERP scope, like on-premises, with annual releases, custom code, and add-ons possible.

Check the references below

  • SAP Help Portal â€“ RISE with SAP Overview
  • SAP Discovery Center â€“ RISE with SAP Services

With RISE, you receive not only S/4HANA licensing but also the infrastructure, BTP credits, Signavio, migration tools, and lifecycle management, all through a single subscription.

Let me know if you need further information

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Parallel Multicast causing random failures in my Message Mapping subprocesses
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

Iâ€™m working on a very large integration that takes a long time to execute since it has many subprocesses running sequentially with a Sequential Multicast, each performing upserts to SuccessFactors.

To improve performance, I moved some of these subprocesses to a Parallel Multicast so they could run at the same time. This successfully cut the execution time in half, but now Iâ€™m occasionally running into random errors in the Message Mappings that donâ€™t seem to make sense.

Some of the errors Iâ€™ve seen include:
com.sap.xi.mapping.camel.XiMappingException: A pseudo attribute name is expected.
com.sap.xi.mapping.camel.XiMappingException: Content is not allowed in prolog.
com.sap.xi.mapping.camel.XiMappingException: Premature end of file. (this one happens most often)

The subprocesses are running in parallel like this:



And the ones that tend to fail are the ones that include routers, like this one:



Iâ€™ve tried running them in Trace mode and reusing the failing payload in the Message Mapping simulation, and it works fine there. I also re-executed the integration with the exact same data, and it succeeded the second time. It looks like the payload is sometimes breaking randomly, which causes the mapping to fail.

Has anyone run into something similar? Any help would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks,
Agustin

entry.title: Multiple SAP HANA Systems on One Host
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP HANA is an in-memory database that supports mission-critical workloads and is a key component of an SAP system that must be protected from failures. Business-critical production HANA databases require a well-designed and tested High Availability and Disaster Recovery (HA/DR) plan to ensure business continuity and minimize downtimeA primary (active) HANA database can be replicated to a secondary instance using SAP HANA System Replication (HSR). HSR continuously replicates data to an alternate instance to ensure that changes persist in the event of a primary instance failure.

SAP does support running multiple SAP HANA systems (SIDS) on a single production SAP HANA hardware installation (or single virtual machine). 

Multiple SAP HANA systems on one host are also known as Multiple Components on One System (MCOS).

SAP support running multiple SAP HANA systems (SIDs) on a single production SAP HANA host. This is restricted to single-host / scale-up scenarios only.  One Hardware which can be segregated for two HANA tenant installations. Filesystem e can be also be segregated which allows us to do maintenance separately.

Few considerations:

  • RAM:

SAP HANA is memory intensive. Sufficient RAM is crucial for optimal performance, potentially 64GB or 128GB or more depending on the data size and workload.

  • CPU:

Adequate CPU resources are needed to handle the processing demands of multiple HANA instances.

  • Disk Space:

Ensure sufficient disk space for the installation binaries, data volumes, log volumes, and trace files for all instances/tenants.

  • Network:

Plan for network configuration, especially if using a multi-host setup or if the databases need to communicate with other systems.

File System structure:

 

        192.168.1.124:/nasData-1a /hana/data/SID1/mnt00001 nfs4 ...

        192.168.1.128:/nasLog-1b /hana/log/SID1/mnt00001 nfs4 ...

        192.168.1.124:/nasData-2a /hana/data/SID2/mnt00001 nfs4 ...

        192.168.1.128:/nasLog-2b /hana/log/SID2/mnt00001 nfs4 ...

 
 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

FS structure for 2 DB SIDâ€™s SDP â€“ is Prod S4 SDS â€“ is for Quality system

 

 

Production support is restricted to SAP HANA 1.0 SPS 09 (and higher) or SAP HANA 2.0 due to the availability of some resource management parameters (for example affinity). Be aware that running multi-SID on one SAP HANA host may impact performance of various types of operations, as contention for computing resources may occur (memory, cpu, i/o, ...).

SAP strongly recommends performing requisite testing in any project before going live; in general, stress/volume testing is recommended in order to provide good indicators of expected performance. When operating a system that features a multi-SID deployment, SAP recommends to actively make use of the resource management features of SAP HANA (e.g. parameters controlling memory limits, and influencing utilization of CPU cores, etc.) in order to optimize performance.

Business critical Production HANA DBâ€™s require a well designed and tested High Availability and Disaster Recovery (HA/DR) for business continuity and allow a SAP technical team to minimize the downtime and increase the application availability during planned and unplanned outages. SAP HANA is an in-memory database that supports mission critical workloads and is a key component of an SAP system that needs to be safeguarded from failures. A primary or active HANA database can be replicated to a secondary instance using SAP HANA System Replication (HSR).

SAP HSR continuously replicates data to ensure that in the event of a failure on the primary instance, changes persist in an alternate instance. In Public Clouds the secondary HANA database instance can either exist within the same region (different Availability Zone) or in a separate region.

 

 

 

SAP systems that are critical to business continuity require a well designed and tested High Availability and Disaster Recovery (HA/DR) framework to maximise application availability during planned and unplanned outages. SAP HANA is an in-memory database that supports mission critical workloads and is a key component of an SAP system that needs to be safeguarded from failures. A primary or active HANA database can be replicated to a secondary instance using SAP HANA System Replication (HSR). SAP HSR continuously replicates data to ensure that in the event of a failure on the primary instance, changes persist in an alternate instance.

To achieve a near zero Recovery Time Objective (RTO), it is necessary for the primary and secondary HANA database instances to have a similar memory capacity. However, if a higher RTO is acceptable, it is possible to operate the secondary HANA database instance with a reduced memory footprint. This can result in considerable cost savings for compute, either by choosing a smaller instance size or leveraging excess memory on the secondary to operate other SAP HANA database workloads.

The reduced memory requirement in the secondary HANA node is achieved by configuring the secondary to not load HANA column data into main memory. A restart is required before promoting it to be primary, at which time it is assumed that the full memory requirement is available. The actual memory demand on secondary host is highly dependent on the HANA System Replication (HSR) configuration and production data change rate. Even by disabling HANA column table loading, the memory demands on the secondary host can go beyond 60% of the actual production HANA memory usage. If the secondary instance is not sized correctly, this can lead to out-of-memory crashes and reduced resilience.

This blog aims at providing a detailed guidance on how to size the secondary HANA database instance while operating with reduced memory footprint with examples for multiple deployment scenarios.

Architecture

There are two common architectures for deploying a secondary HANA database with a lean, or reduced memory footprint in single Hardware.  In this blog we differentiate between them with the terms â€˜smaller secondaryâ€™ and â€˜shared secondaryâ€™. Smaller secondary is where the infrastructure is sized smaller than the primary, and then re-sized on takeover. This is sometimes referred to as Pilot Light DR as in the blog Rapidly recover mission-critical systems in a disaster. Shared secondary is where the unused memory is utilized by a non-production or sacrificial instance. SLES documentation refers to this as â€˜Cost Optimized Scenarioâ€˜.

In both these scenarios, preload of column tables is disabled on the secondary HANA database. The specific configuration to implement this change is to set the HANA database parameter preload_column_tables to false. This configuration needs to be changed to â€˜trueâ€™ before promoting this instance as primary. Given the manual intervention required and the time taken following a takeover to load the column tables before the HANA database is open for SQL connections, these scenarios are more relevant for a Disaster Recovery (DR) than a High Availability (HA) solution.

Shared secondary

A common use case for a shared secondary scenario is to operate an active quality (QAS) instance along with the secondary HANA database instance on the same host, also called MCOS (Multiple Components One System). This setup requires additional storage to operate the additional instance(s). During a takeover, the instance with lower priority (QAS) can be shutdown to make the underlying host resources available for production workloads.

 

 

For both the scenarios, the secondary HANA database instance configuration is set to preload_column_tables = false. The default value of this parameter is â€˜trueâ€™ and has to be explicitly changed on the secondary instance to operate with reduced memory. This change is made in HANA database configuration file (global.ini) located in the file path (/hana/shared/<SID>/global/hdb/custom/config).

HANA SR Operation modes

The two operation modes supported by HANA System Replication (HSR) to setup a secondary system are logreplay and delta_datashipping. A high-level comparison between logreplay and delta_datashipping operation modes is presented below.

SAP HANA System Replication Operation Modes

#

Criteria

logreplay

delta_datashipping

1

Operational Behavior

Logs are shipped and continuously applied on the secondary system.

Delta data is shipped from the primary to the secondary occasionally (default 10 min). Logs are only shipped, not applied, until a takeover.

2

Recovery Time

Shorter takeover window, as logs are applied continuously until a failure occurs.

Relatively higher takeover time.

3

Data Transfer Needs

Only logs are shipped, resulting in comparatively lower data transfer needs.

Transfer of both delta data and logs adds to higher data transfers.

4

Network Bandwidth

Due to reduced data transfers, this mode requires relatively lower bandwidth between sites.

This mode requires higher bandwidth between sites.

5

Memory Footprint on DR Instance

Significantly higher memory is required as the column store needs to be loaded for faster delta merge.

The memory footprint is much smaller because the column store isn't loaded into the main memory when column preload is disabled.

6

Multi-tier Replication

Supported

Supported

7

Multi-target Replication

Supported

Not supported

8

Secondary Time Travel

Supported

Not supported

 

 

It is worth noting that in a 3-Tier replication setup, a mix of operation modes is not supported. For example if the primary and secondary HANA database instances are configured to use logreplay for HSR, then delta_datashipping operation mode cannot be used between the secondary and tertiary systems and vice-versa.

SAP Guidance on disabling column preload

The actual memory usage on the secondary host is dependent on the HANA replication operation mode configuration and the preload setting for column tables. Hence it is important to understand the sizing requirements for different operation modes in a HANA System Replication setup. The below chart is an excerpt from SAP Note : 1999880 â€“ FAQ: SAP HANA System Replication (SAP Support Portal login required)

 

As per the above guidance, even with preload = off, the minimum memory requirements for operation mode â€˜logreplayâ€™ also factors in the column store memory size of tables with modifications . As a rule of thumb, consider the size of column store tables with data modified in the previous 30 days from current date of evaluation.

SAP Note 1969700 â€“ SQL Statement Collection for SAP HANA provides a collection of SQL scripts that can be used for analysing various administration and performance aspects of SAP HANA database. With minor changes to one of the scripts from this collection, titled â€˜HANA_Tables_ColumnStore_Columns_LastTouchTimeâ€™, it is possible to provide a rough estimate for the minimum memory required to accommodate these tables. For exact steps of executing this script, refer to the â€˜Additional informationâ€™ section at the end of this blog.

In the following sections, the examples provide details on how to evaluate sizing when deployed in a Shared secondary scenario. Although not shown, a similar sizing exercise is applicable to the Smaller secondary scenario, without the additional considerations of running a second HANA database instance (for example QAS) on the same host.

Option 1 â€“ HSR with Operation Mode: logreplay

In the following example, the primary and secondary production HANA database instances are deployed on two 9TiB High Memory instances. The secondary instance host also hosts a Quality Assurance (QAS) HANA Database Instance. To be able to deploy these instances, the global_allocation_limit for all the three HANA database instances (PRD-Primary, PRD-Secondary, QAS) needs to be evaluated. Following section illustrates how to derive these values.

 

 

 

In the subsequent sections, Global Allocation Limit is referred as â€˜GALâ€™.

  • GAL for Primary instance

On the Primary instance, global_allocation_limit is not set in this example (default value=0 and unit is MB). A default value does not limit the amount of physical memory that can be used by the database. However, as per the SAP Note 1681092 â€“ Multiple SAP HANA systems (SIDs) on the same underlying server(s), maximum allocation to HANA database by operating system follows the rule of 90% of the first 64 GB of available physical memory on the host plus 97% of remaining physical memory.

  • GAL for Secondary instance

SAPâ€™s guidance for minimum memory requirements for secondary HANA database instance with preload=off and logreplay operation mode is, â€˜Row store size + Column store memory size of tables with modifications + 50 GBâ€™. As an example, on the primary instance, the SQL script â€˜HANA_Tables_ColumnStore_Columns_LastTouchTimeâ€™ was executed and the column tables with modifications for the previous 30 days is identified as 3077 GB. For detailed steps of executing this script, refer to the â€˜Additional informationâ€™ section of this blog.

 

 

Similarly, using SQL script â€˜HANA_Memory_Overviewâ€™ from SAP Note 1969700 â€“ SQL Statement Collection for SAP HANA, the memory requirements for â€˜Row storeâ€™ can be determined. An example value of 153 GB is considered for the following evaluation.

Memory required (min) = Row store size

                        + Column store memory size of tables with modifications

                        + 50 GB

Ex: (153 + 3077 + 50) GB = 3280 GB

GAL for DR = 3280 GB^

  ^Convert to MB before changing GAL in the system

Note: This value provides the minimum sizing guidance only. It is recommended to allocate additional headroom of 10-20% of this value to accommodate any immediate spike in column store table modifications.

Similarly, global_allocation_limit (GAL) has to be set for the second HANA database instance (QAS) running on the DR site. According to  the SAP Note 1681092 â€“ Multiple SAP HANA systems (SIDs) on the same underlying server(s), the sum total of all HANA database allocation limits on a particular host should not exceed 90% of first 64 GB of available physical memory on the host plus 97% of remaining physical memory.

Î£ [(GAL_DR) + (GAL_QAS)] â‰¤ {(0.9 * 64) + [0.97 * (Phys Mem GB - 64)]}

Applying this guidance to our example of 9 TiB(9896 GB)  bare metal instance is as follows.

Î£ [(GAL_DR) + (GAL_QAS)]  â‰¤  {[0.9 * 64] + [0.97 * (9896 - 64)]} GB

                          â‰¤  9595 GB

The total available memory for all HANA database instances is 9595 GB, while the total available physical memory on the bare metal instance is 9TiB (9896 GB). As the HANA DR instance memory sizing is derived at 3280 GB, the remaining size can be the maximum allocatable memory for QAS instance.

Î£ [ (GAL_DR) + (GAL_QAS)]  â‰¤ 9595 GB

Î£ [ 3280 GB  + (GAL_QAS)]  â‰¤ 9595 GB

GAL for QAS: The maximum allowed value for GAL_QAS = 6314 GB^

    ^Convert to MB before changing GAL in the system

Option 2 â€“ HSR with Operation Mode: delta_datashipping

This section provides an overview of HANA System Replication deployed with â€˜delta_datashippingâ€™ operation mode and the procedure to evaluate the memory sizing for each individual instance.

 

 

 

  • GAL for Secondary instance

 

SAPâ€™s guidance for minimum memory requirements for secondary HANA database instance with preload=off and delta_datashipping operation mode is as follows. Applying this guidance to our example scenario to derive GAL for DR is as follows

Max [64 GB, (Row store size + 20 GB)]

Applying this guidance to our example scenario to derive GAL for DR is as follows

Max [64 GB, (153 + 20 GB)]

GAL for DR: The minimum required value for GAL_DR = 173 GB^

    ^Convert to MB before changing GAL in the system

The total available memory for all HANA database instances is 9595 GB, while the total available physical memory on the bare metal instance is 9TiB (9896 GB). In the previous step, secondary HANA database instance memory sizing is derived at 173 GB, the remaining size on the host can be the maximum allocatable memory for QAS instance.

Î£ [ (GAL_DR) + (GAL_QAS)]   â‰¤ 9595 GB

Î£ [ 173 GB   + (GAL_QAS)] â‰¤  9595 GB

GAL for QAS: The maximum allowed value for GAL_QAS = 9422 GB^

   ^Convert to MB before changing GAL in the system

Conclusion

This blog highlights that the cost savings of deploying a secondary HANA database instance with a reduced memory footprint may not be realized with logreplay operation mode. This is because of the higher memory demands of column store being loaded into the main memory of secondary HANA database and occurs irrespective of the column table preload setting. This behavior is by design for continuous log replay. In addition, there is a requirement to constantly monitor column store data growth on the primary and adapt memory allocations on the secondary to avoid out-of-memory (OOM) issues on secondary. The operation mode delta_datashipping facilitates better cost savings in comparison to logreplay while disabling the preload of column tables on secondary HANA database instance. However, this choice comes with limitations which may include a higher recovery time and an increased demand for network bandwidth between the replication sites.

Opting for delta_datashipping is usually a trade-off between cost considerations and other limitations of this operation mode as explained in this blog. With relaxed RTO requirements and higher network bandwidth between the replication sites, the use of â€˜delta_datashippingâ€™ can be promoted. Also, with larger database instances, the potential for cost savings is higher. This is because the memory footprint on the secondary has a minimum requirement of row store memory and buffer requirements even for smaller database instances. The association between various factors that influence the choice of a particular operation mode and the potential for cost benefits with delta_datashipping option are represented in the following diagram. These factors are independent of each other and can individually influence the ability to use â€˜delta_datashippingâ€™ and thereby the cost benefits.

It is also important to understand that the memory requirement calculation for the secondary and subsequent setting of global_allocation_limit, is an iterative process. As the production database size grows, eventually the column store demand for delta merge also grows on the secondary instance. Hence, the memory allocations of secondary and optionally, other HANA database instances provisioned on the same hardware should be monitored periodically and also after mass data loads, go-lives and SAP system specific life-cycle events.

Additional Information

Following are the steps to execute the SAP SQL script.

  1. Download the file SQLStatements.zip which is an attachment to SAP Note 1969700 â€“ SQL Statement Collection for SAP HANA
  2. Unzip the file and identify the SQL script named HANA_Tables_ColumnStore_Columns_LastTouchTime_2.00.x+.txt (for HANA 1.0, choose a different version of the same script).
  3. Modify the script with the following two changes.

TOUCH_TYPE

  Identify the section with title ' /* Modification section */'

  Identify the parameter 'TOUCH_TYPE' and enter the value as 'MODIFY'

Ex: 'MODIFY' TOUCH_TYPE,       /* ACCESS, SELECT, MODIFY */

BEGIN_TIME

  Identify the section with title ' /* Modification section */'

  Identify the parameter 'BEGIN_TIME' and key in the value as 'C-D30'

Ex: 'C-D30' BEGIN_TIME,

  1. Execute the script on the HANA Production tenant DB using any of the SQL editors of SAP HANA Cockpit, SAP HANA Studio and DBACOCKPIT or the tool hdbsql.
  2. Identify the output under the column â€˜MEM_GBâ€™ for the column store size that has been modified in the previous 30 days from the date of script execution.

entry.title: S/4HANA CDS View with CDC enabled
entry.content:
Hello!

I have a question regarding CDC logging tables being shared by both SLT and ODP subscribers.

Currently we are testing this functionality in QA system and the changes are captured as expected.

One issue we see is that same Subscriber logging table is being consumed by both SLT and ODP subscribers and I would like to know if this is a normal behaviour.

Our QA system had a copy of Production recently and it shows the subscribers from Prod of SLT sharing the same logging table as the ODP subscriber. Because of this, the logging tables are getting piled up and not cleaned up automatically after the records are consumed by target system via CDS View. The SLT subscribers were present before the CDS view was created.

Will this be a problem when we deploy this CDS view and subscription in production?

In every article around and even SAP has mentioned that the Subscriber logging tables are unique per subscriber but it doesnâ€™t seem so with what we see in QA.

If thatâ€™s the case shouldnâ€™t there be a new logging table for CDS view when the CDS subscription was created?

Highly appreciate your response in this! Thank you.

entry.title: Re: movement type 343 with MIGO with PO reference
entry.content:
Hello

Have you tried one of the following

1. Use Movement Type 343 Without PO Reference in MIGO

You can post a 343 movement without referencing the PO in MIGO.

Path: MIGO â†’ Transfer Posting â†’ Others â†’ Enter movement type 343 â†’ fill in material, plant, and quantity.

2. Custom Enhancement (If PO Reference is Mandatory)

If your business process requires a PO reference (e.g., for tracking, reporting, or compliance):

You may need to enhance MIGO via a BAdI (e.g., MB_MIGO_BADI) or create a custom transaction that supports 343 with PO reference.

Be cautious â€” SAP doesnâ€™t recommend using PO reference for 343 in standard, as it may conflict with GR-based processes.

3. Use Fiori App (If Applicable)

Some Fiori apps or custom tiles allow more flexible goods movement.

Check if a custom Fiori app is available or can be created for this specific movement with PO reference.

Best regards

entry.title: Re: Regenerate DME where BCM is Activated in S4HANA
entry.content:
Dear Hitesh ðŸ˜€

Yes, in SAP S/4HANA with Bank Communication Management (BCM), once a DME file (payment medium file) is generated and listed in the "Manage Payment Media" Fiori app, it becomes part of the BCM processing flow. However, if the file is deleted or moved, you generally cannot regenerate it directly from the "Manage Payment Media" app. But depending on the situation, there are some ways to regenerate it.

Option 1: Use Program RFFOAVIS_FPAYM or Payment Medium Workbench Again

you can regenerate the DME file using:

Transaction: FBPM (Payment Medium Workbench)
or
Transaction: F110 / F111 (if applicable for payment run)
and then call the payment medium generation again if it wasn't cleared

Option 2: Re-trigger Payment Medium Generation Manually via GUI

Go to Transaction: FBPM â€“ Payment Medium Workbench

Enter the Payment Run Date / ID / Payment Method and execute

If the payment data is still available and not locked, the system will allow you to regenerate the DME file

Option 3 is more of a workaround and requires reversal and re-approval: Re-execute Payment via Fiori App (Not Ideal)

If business allows, you can:

Reverse the payment

Reprocess it through BCM

Let the approval workflow generate a new DME

Option 4 is a custom development : Custom Z-Report to Re-generate DME

Some customers build a Z-Program to allow:

Re-execution of the DME file generation from historical data (e.g., from REGUH, PAYR)

Without reprocessing the payment

Best regards

entry.title: Re: SAP CI Just Started Talking to AI : Introducing the new AI Adapter for SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Hi @hsonnenahalli , 

Thanks for checking out this blog! Yes, thatâ€™s absolutely possible. In fact, itâ€™s always a best practice to design such mechanisms centrally rather than building one per integration scenario.

With this blog, Iâ€™ve tried to show how the AI Adapter can be leveraged, and your idea aligns perfectly with that. By pulling exceptions into a JMS queue and routing them to an AI service, you not only centralize error handling but also gain flexibility to extend the process further â€” for example, enriching the context, prioritizing errors, or even auto-suggesting resolutions before assigning them.

In the fact that once you have this central AI-enabled mechanism, you can plug in multiple integrations without making changes at the iFlow level. Thatâ€™s where the scalability and maintainability benefits kick in.

Would love to hear if youâ€™re already experimenting with this approach!

Thanks!

Punith

entry.title: SAP Databricks in SAP Business Data Cloud â€“ a Typical Machine Learning Workflow
entry.content:
With SAP Databricks you have access to an amazing set of capabilities to work with your BDC Data Products and other data.

 

This blog post is part of a series exploring SAP Databricks in SAP Business Data Cloud:

Part 1 â€“ SQL analytics with SAP Data Products
Part 2 â€“ Build and deploy Mosaic AI and Agent Tools
Part 3 â€“ How to use AutoML to forecast sales data
Part 4 â€“ Connect SAP Data Products with non-SAP data from AWS S3
Part 5 â€“ End-to-end integration: SAP Databricks, SAP Datasphere, and SAP Analytics Cloud
Part 6 â€“ Create inferences for application integration with SAP Build 

Part 7 - SAP Databricks in SAP Business Data Cloud â€“ a Typical Machine Learning Workflow

 

In this blog post weâ€™ll look at the typical workflow you would undertake when trying to train a machine learning model.

  • Visualise and understand your data
  • Optimise for hyperparameters to tune your model
  • Explore hyperparameter sweep results with MLflow
  • Register the best performing model in MLflow
  • Apply the registered model with batch inference and Databricks Model Serving

Weâ€™ll use a classic machine learning dataset to predict whether a wine is of high quality or not (a data classification problem). Of course you have access to a range of SAP Data Products, but by using this dataset you donâ€™t even need a connected S/4HANA system to follow along. The dataset also comes built-in with SAP Databricks.

 

Wine Quality Classification

We will train a binary classification model to predict the quality of Portuguese "Vinho Verde" wine based on the wine's physicochemical properties.

The dataset is from the UCI Machine Learning Repository, presented in Modelling wine preferences by data mining from physicochemical properties [Cortez et al., 2009]. And the good news is that this dataset comes preloaded with your Databricks system.

 

Letâ€™s create a new notebook in our SAP Databricks system and in a new cell we will install some module dependencies.

%pip install --upgrade -Uqqq mlflow>=3.0 xgboost hyperopt
%restart_python

Installs:

  • The latest mlflow for experiment tracking and general MLOps
  • xgboost being a fantastic and very popular machine learning model architecture (it dominates many Kaggle competitions)
  • hyperopt is a python library used for hyperparameter optimisation. It intelligently searches for the optimal hyperparameters to use when training a machine learning model.
  • The `%restart_python` magic command it necessary in Databricks notebooks because they use long running Python processes and this ensures that the system path and any newly installed python packages are being used.

 

Next, we create a cell to connect MLFlow to the Databricks Unity Catalog (it would otherwise use an sqlite data store) and create a few constants that will be used later:

import mlflow
mlflow.set_registry_uri("databricks-uc")

CATALOG_NAME = "workspace"
SCHEMA_NAME = "default"
MODEL_NAME = "wine_quality_classifier"

 

Read and Understand the DATA

Read the white wine quality and red wine quality CSV datasets and merge them into a single DataFrame. Note theses datasets come with your Databricks system.

import pandas as pd

white_wine = pd.read_csv("/databricks-datasets/wine-quality/winequality-white.csv", sep=";")
red_wine = pd.read_csv("/databricks-datasets/wine-quality/winequality-red.csv", sep=";")

 

Merge the two DataFrames into a single dataset, with a new binary feature "is_red" that indicates whether the wine is red or white.

red_wine['is_red'] = 1
white_wine['is_red'] = 0

data = pd.concat([red_wine, white_wine], axis=0)

# cast to float as a best practice (avoids dtype issues with NaN's later)
data["is_red"] = data["is_red"].astype("float32")

# Remove spaces from column names
data.rename(columns=lambda x: x.replace(' ', '_'), inplace=True)

Now we have one dataset with a mix of white and red wines.

 

Visualize data

Before training a model, explore the dataset using popular charting libraries: Seaborn and Matplotlib.

Plot a histogram of the dependent variable, quality.

import seaborn as sns
sns.displot(data.quality, kde=False)

Looks like quality scores are normally distributed between 3 and 9. Define a wine as high quality if it has quality >= 7.

high_quality = (data.quality >= 7)
data.quality = high_quality

# cast to float as a best practice (avoids dtype issues with NaN's later)
data["quality"] = data["quality"].astype("float32")

 

Box plots are useful for identifying correlations between features and a binary label. Create box plots for each feature to compare high-quality and low-quality wines. Significant differences in the box plots indicate good predictors of quality.

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

dims = (3, 4)

f, axes = plt.subplots(dims[0], dims[1], figsize=(25, 15))
axis_i, axis_j = 0, 0
for col in data.columns:
  if col == 'is_red' or col == 'quality':
    continue # Box plots cannot be used on indicator variables
  sns.boxplot(x=high_quality, y=data[col], ax=axes[axis_i, axis_j])
  axis_j += 1
  if axis_j == dims[1]:
    axis_i += 1
    axis_j = 0

In the above box plots, a few variables stand out as good univariate predictors of quality.

  • In the alcohol box plot, the median alcohol content of high-quality wines is greater than even the 75th quantile of low-quality wines. High alcohol content is correlated with quality.
  • In the density box plot, low quality wines have a greater density than high quality wines. Density is inversely correlated with quality.

 

Preprocess data

Before training a model, check for missing values and split the data into training and validation sets.

data.isna().any()

There are no missing values.

 

Note: Often you will need to take advantage of feature engineering at this step. This is where you can build new features as combinations of your existing dataâ€¦ for example multiplying two existing feature columns together to create a new column may enable the model to find better patterns in the data.

For time series data it can be very helpful to generate a new feature column called â€œQtrâ€ for example to show which qtr of the year that data point is in based on a date. You will need to experiment with thisâ€¦

 

Prepare the dataset to train a baseline model

Split the input data into 3 sets:

  • Train (60% of the dataset used to train the model)
  • Validation (20% of the dataset used to tune the hyperparameters)
  • Test (20% of the dataset used to report the true performance of the model on an unseen dataset)
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split

X = data.drop(["quality"], axis=1)
y = data.quality

# Split out the training data
X_train, X_rem, y_train, y_rem = train_test_split(X, y, train_size=0.6, random_state=123)

# Split the remaining data equally into validation and test
X_val, X_test, y_val, y_test = train_test_split(X_rem, y_rem, test_size=0.5, random_state=123)

 

Train a baseline model

This task seems well suited to a random forest classifier, since the output is binary and there may be interactions between multiple variables.

Build a simple classifier using scikit-learn and use MLflow to keep track of the model's accuracy and save the model for later use.

 

Note: When this cell is executed an MLFlow Experiment will be created by default (automatically) using the full path of this Notebook. In production experiments its best practice to set the Experiment name with mlflow.set_experiment() because you may work on the problem over multiple Notebooks and/or users.

import mlflow.pyfunc
import mlflow.sklearn
import numpy as np
import sklearn
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifier
from sklearn.metrics import roc_auc_score
from mlflow.models.signature import infer_signature
from mlflow.utils.environment import _mlflow_conda_env
import cloudpickle
import time

# The predict method of sklearn's RandomForestClassifier returns a binary classification (0 or 1). 
# The following code creates a wrapper function, SklearnModelWrapper, that uses 
# the predict_proba method to return the probability that the observation belongs to each class. 

class SklearnModelWrapper(mlflow.pyfunc.PythonModel):
  def __init__(self, model):
    self.model = model
    
  def predict(self, context, model_input):
    return self.model.predict_proba(model_input)[:,1]

# mlflow.start_run creates a new MLflow run to track the performance of this model. 
# Within the context, you call mlflow.log_param to keep track of the parameters used, and
# mlflow.log_metric to record metrics like accuracy.
with mlflow.start_run(run_name='rf_baseline_n10'):
  n_estimators = 10
  model = RandomForestClassifier(n_estimators=n_estimators, random_state=np.random.RandomState(123))
  model.fit(X_train, y_train)

  # predict_proba returns [prob_negative, prob_positive], so slice the output with [:, 1]
  predictions_test = model.predict_proba(X_test)[:,1]
  auc_score = roc_auc_score(y_test, predictions_test)
  mlflow.log_param('n_estimators', n_estimators)
  # Use the area under the ROC curve as a metric.
  mlflow.log_metric('auc', auc_score)
  wrappedModel = SklearnModelWrapper(model)
  
  # MLflow contains utilities to create a conda environment used to serve models.
  # The necessary dependencies are added to a conda.yaml file which is logged along with the model.
  conda_env = _mlflow_conda_env(
        additional_conda_deps=None,
        additional_pip_deps=["cloudpickle=={}".format(cloudpickle.__version__), "scikit-learn=={}".format(sklearn.__version__)],
        additional_conda_channels=None,
    )

  # Here we log the model and register it to Unity Catalog in one go.
  # MLflow automatically generates model signatures when you provide
  # an `input_example` during model logging. This works for all model 
  # flavors and is the recommended approach for most use cases.
  # By registering this model to Unity Catalog, you can easily reference
  # the model from anywhere within Databricks.
  # 
  sample_input = X_train.head(5)

  model_version = mlflow.pyfunc.log_model(
    name="rf_baseline",
    python_model=wrappedModel,
    conda_env=conda_env,
    input_example=sample_input,
    registered_model_name=MODEL_NAME,
  )

Note how the trained model is registered when logging it to MLFlow. This can be done separately as we will see later. If you are running many experiments there is no need to register every model but only the best model.

Review the learned feature importances output by the model. As illustrated by the previous boxplots, alcohol and density are important in predicting quality.

feature_importances = pd.DataFrame(model.feature_importances_, index=X_train.columns.tolist(), columns=['importance'])
feature_importances.sort_values('importance', ascending=False)

 

You logged the Area Under the ROC Curve (AUC) to MLflow. Click the Experiment icon in the right sidebar to display the Experiment Runs sidebar. The model achieved an AUC of 0.854. A random classifier would have an AUC of 0.5, and higher AUC values are better.

The ROC AUC is a good evaluation metric for binary classification problems like we have here (is good quality / is not good quality).

 

Next, assign this model the "Best" tag, and load it into this notebook from Unity Catalog.

from mlflow.tracking import MlflowClient

client = MlflowClient()
client.set_registered_model_alias(MODEL_NAME, "Best", model_version.registered_model_version)

In Unity Catalog, the model version now has the tag "Best". You can now refer to the model using the path models:/{model_name}@Best.

 

Experiment with a new model

The random forest model performed well even without hyperparameter tuning.

Let's now try and do better and use the xgboost library to train a more accurate model. Run a hyperparameter sweep to train multiple models in parallel, using Hyperopt and Trials. As before, MLflow tracks the performance of each parameter configuration.

Note: We must use Trials and not SparkTrials in SAP Databricks, because SparkTrials tries to access the underlying JVM which is not supported on serverless compute.

We use the validation dataset here for hyperparameter search.

Note this training cell takes over 20mins to complete!

from hyperopt import fmin, tpe, hp, Trials, STATUS_OK
from hyperopt.pyll import scope
from math import exp
import mlflow.xgboost
import numpy as np
import xgboost as xgb

search_space = {
  'max_depth': scope.int(hp.quniform('max_depth', 4, 100, 1)),
  'learning_rate': hp.loguniform('learning_rate', -3, 0),
  'reg_alpha': hp.loguniform('reg_alpha', -5, -1),
  'reg_lambda': hp.loguniform('reg_lambda', -6, -1),
  'min_child_weight': hp.loguniform('min_child_weight', -1, 3),
  'objective': 'binary:logistic',
  'seed': 123, # Set a seed for deterministic training
}

def train_model(params):
  # With MLflow autologging, hyperparameters and the trained model are automatically logged to MLflow.
  mlflow.xgboost.autolog()
  with mlflow.start_run(nested=True):
    train = xgb.DMatrix(data=X_train, label=y_train)
    validation = xgb.DMatrix(data=X_val, label=y_val)
    # Pass in the validation set so xgb can track an evaluation metric. XGBoost terminates training when the evaluation metric
    # is no longer improving.
    booster = xgb.train(params=params, dtrain=train, num_boost_round=1000,
                        evals=[(validation, "validation")], early_stopping_rounds=50)
    validation_predictions = booster.predict(validation)
    auc_score = roc_auc_score(y_val, validation_predictions)
    mlflow.log_metric('auc', auc_score)

    # Don't register the model in one-step here - let the hyperparameter search find the best one first.
    #signature = infer_signature(X_train, booster.predict(train))
    #mlflow.xgboost.log_model(booster, name="xgboost", signature=signature)
    sample_input = X_train.head(5)
    mlflow.xgboost.log_model(booster, name="xgboost", input_example=sample_input)
    
    # Set the loss to -1*auc_score so fmin maximizes the auc_score
    return {'status': STATUS_OK, 'loss': -1*auc_score, 'booster': booster.attributes()}

# Use Trials instead of SparkTrials
trials = Trials()

# Run fmin within an MLflow run context so that each hyperparameter configuration is logged as a child run of a parent
# run called "xgboost_models" .
with mlflow.start_run(run_name='xgboost_models'):
  best_params = fmin(
    fn=train_model, 
    space=search_space, 
    algo=tpe.suggest, 
    max_evals=96,
    trials=trials,
  )

 

Use MLflow to view the results

Open up the Experiments sidebar to see the MLflow runs. Click on Date next to the down arrow to display a menu, and select 'auc' to display the runs sorted by the auc metric. The highest auc value is ~0.90. Remember that this is against the validation data.

Hyperparameter tuning (runs) score against the validation dataset!

MLflow tracks the parameters and performance metrics of each run. Click the External Link icon at the top of the Experiment Runs sidebar to navigate to the MLflow Runs Table.

 

Update the best version of the wine_quality_classifier model

Earlier, you saved the baseline model to Unity Catalog with the name wine_quality_classifier. Now you can update wine_quality_classifier to a more accurate model from the hyperparameter sweep. Because you used MLflow to log the model produced by each hyperparameter configuration, you can use MLflow to identify the best performing run and save the model from that run to Unity Catalog.

best_run = mlflow.search_runs(order_by=['metrics.auc DESC']).iloc[0]
print(f'AUC of Best Run: {best_run["metrics.auc"]}')

 

new_model_version = mlflow.register_model(f"runs:/{best_run.run_id}/model", MODEL_NAME)

# Registering the model takes a few seconds, so add a small delay
import time
time.sleep(15)

 

 

Click Models in the left sidebar to see that the wine_quality_classifier model now has a new versions. Assign the "Best" alias to the new version.

from mlflow.tracking import MlflowClient

client = MlflowClient()
client.set_registered_model_alias(MODEL_NAME, "Best", new_model_version.version)

 

Clients that call load_model() using the "Best" alias now get the new model.

>> Let's get the AUC score against the Test data:

model = mlflow.pyfunc.load_model(f"models:/{MODEL_NAME}@Best")

from sklearn.metrics import roc_auc_score
print(f'AUC: {roc_auc_score(y_test, model.predict(X_test))}')

 

The new version achieved a better score (AUC = 0.90) on the test set.

 

Batch inference

There are many scenarios where you might want to evaluate a model on a corpus of new data. For example, you may have a fresh batch of data or may need to compare the performance of two models on the same corpus of data.

Evaluate the model on data stored in a Delta table, using Spark to run the computation in parallel.

# To simulate a new corpus of data, save the existing X_train data to a Delta table. 
# In the real world, this would be a new batch of data.
spark_df = spark.createDataFrame(X_train)

table_name = f"{CATALOG_NAME}.{SCHEMA_NAME}.wine_data"

(spark_df
  .write
  .format("delta")
  .mode("overwrite")
  .option("overwriteSchema",True)
  .saveAsTable(table_name)
)

 

Load the model into a Spark UDF, so it can be applied to the Delta table.

apply_model_udf = mlflow.pyfunc.spark_udf(spark, f"models:/{MODEL_NAME}@Best")
# Read the "new data" from the Unity Catalog table
new_data = spark.read.table(f"{CATALOG_NAME}.{SCHEMA_NAME}.wine_data")
from pyspark.sql.functions import struct

# Apply the model to the new data
udf_inputs = struct(*(X_train.columns.tolist()))

new_data = new_data.withColumn(
  "prediction",
  apply_model_udf(udf_inputs)
)

display(new_data)

Each row now has an associated prediction. Note that the xgboost function is using the objective "binary:logistic" so the predictions shown here are probabilities.

We also add a is_good_quality column:

from pyspark.sql.functions import col, when

new_data = new_data.withColumn("prediction", col("prediction")[0])

new_data = new_data.withColumn(
  "is_good_quality",
  when(col("prediction") > 0.5, True).otherwise(False)
)
display(new_data)

Overwrite the table with the new columns:

(new_data
  .write
  .format("delta")
  .mode("overwrite")
  .option("overwriteSchema", True)
  .saveAsTable(table_name)
)

# Enable Change Data Feed for the table
# Seems that we can only add this option via SQL!!
spark.sql(f"ALTER TABLE {table_name} SET TBLPROPERTIES (delta.enableChangeDataFeed = true)")

 

Serve the model

To productionize the model for low latency predictions, use Mosaic AI Model Serving to deploy the model to an endpoint. The following cell shows how to use the MLflow Deployments SDK to create a model serving endpoint (which can also be done view the Serving menu on the left).

 

First of all, letâ€™s just show the current modelâ€™s name and best version

# Get the model vesion we tagged as @Best
from mlflow.tracking import MlflowClient
best_ver = MlflowClient().get_model_version_by_alias(MODEL_NAME, "Best").version
print(MODEL_NAME, best_ver)

 

Check if any versions of this model are already being served and delete them

from mlflow.deployments import get_deploy_client

client = get_deploy_client("databricks")
endpoints = client.list_endpoints()

deployed = False
deployed_versions = []
for ep in endpoints:
    ep_detail = client.get_endpoint(ep["name"])
    for entity in ep_detail.get("config", {}).get("served_models", []):
        if entity.get("model_name") == MODEL_NAME or entity.get("model_name").endswith(MODEL_NAME):
            deployed = True
            deployed_versions.append(str(entity.get("model_version")))
            # Delete the serving endpoint if the model is already deployed
            client.delete_endpoint(ep["name"])

if deployed_versions:
    deployed_versions_str = ", ".join(deployed_versions)
else:
    deployed_versions_str = ""

display(spark.createDataFrame([{"model_name": MODEL_NAME, "deployed": deployed, "deployed_versions": deployed_versions_str, "action": "deleting..."}]))

 

 

Creating the endpoint can take 5+ minutes...

# the "name" property can't include special chars so we drop the catalog and schema from the model_name

from mlflow.deployments import get_deploy_client

client = get_deploy_client("databricks")
endpoint = client.create_endpoint(
    name="wine-model-endpoint",
    config={
        "served_entities": [
            {
                "name": MODEL_NAME,
                "entity_name": f"{CATALOG_NAME}.{SCHEMA_NAME}.{MODEL_NAME}",
                "entity_version": best_ver,
                "workload_size": "Small",
                "scale_to_zero_enabled": True
            }
        ],
      }
)

 

Test the Model Serving Endpoint

Navigate to User Settings -> Developer and create an Access Token for calling the serving endpoint.

Ensure the model is being served as this can take 5-10 mins.

In the below cells the notebook will:

  1. Ask for your access token
  2. Setup a payload (the required inputs for your model)
  3. Call the model serving endpoint!

 

from getpass import getpass
token = getpass("ðŸ”‘  Paste your Databricks token: ")

 

Setup the api call request payload with sample wine quality data:

payload = {
  "dataframe_split": {
    "columns": [
      "fixed_acidity", "volatile_acidity", "citric_acid", "residual_sugar",
      "chlorides", "free_sulfur_dioxide", "total_sulfur_dioxide",
      "density", "pH", "sulphates", "alcohol", "is_red"
    ],
    "data": [
      [7.3, 0.19, 0.27, 1.6, 0.027, 35, 136, 0.99248, 3.38, 0.54, 11, 0],
      [7.8, 0.88, 0.00, 2.6, 0.098, 25, 67, 0.9968, 3.20, 0.68, 9.8, 1]
    ]
  }

 

Use the python requests package to make an api call to the SAP Databricks Model Serving Endpoint.

 

Make sure to update the endpoint uri below to match your current SAP Databricks system!

import os, json, requests

url   = "https://<uri>.cloud.databricks.com/serving-endpoints/wine-model-endpoint/invocations"

resp = requests.post(
    url,
    headers={
        "Authorization": f"Bearer {token}",
        "Content-Type": "application/json"
    },
    data=json.dumps(payload),
    timeout=60
)

if resp.status_code == 404:
    print("The endpoint is still deploying.")
else:
    print(resp.json())
    for i, score in enumerate(resp.json()["predictions"], start=1):
        is_good = score >= 0.5          # quality flag
        print(f"Row {i}: {score:.3f}  âžœ  Good quality? {is_good}")

 

You can use this API endpoint to perform inference from your own applications â€“ as is done with blog post : â€œPart 6 â€“ Create inferences for application integration with SAP Build â€ in the series.

 

Conclusion

Weâ€™ve seen in this notebook, if you have followed along, the typical pattern of training a machine learning model.

  • It always starts with understanding the data available. Visualising the data with histograms and box plots as shown here can be a great help. Use tools like ChatGPT to assist in the best ways to flesh out information about your data
  • It can often be helpful to create a quick baseline model just to see that we can do better than random luck with the training data
  • Use a hyperparameter optimisation tool to help search for the ideal parameters to tune the best model. Be very careful with the split of training, validation and test data and ensure that there can never be any overlap. Research how to do this if using time-series data
  • Use MLFlow to log training experiments and their generated models. Assign tags to highlight specific or â€œbestâ€ models.
  • Look at Batch Inference or Model Serving.
    • The former (batch) being ideal if you want to batch score a table of data and potentially share it back to BDC to be used in analytics models. Make use of scheduled notebooks to keep the data up to date and to train the model on new data
    • Use Model Serving to expose an endpoint for real-time applications to make predictions.

Not completely clear how you are adding the links in your xsd file?

Crystal Reports is a relational database reporting tool, meaning all tables must be linked.

Which CR is detecting it's not linked and why it's adding a second data source.

Click on the Links table and manually link the tables.

You could also preview the report in CRD and export the report to XML format and see what CR generates.

FYI, CR will create an Alias *_1 appended to the connection if it finds a duplicate.

Also, using spaces in field names should not matter, you just can't use any character from the top row of your keyboard, those are usually reserved.

entry.title: Re: Empty Bubbles in Demo Mode in SAP Enable Now Recordings
entry.content:
Hi Joketubee,

The information in the Demo and Practice mode fields is coming from standard texts within the Recording Dictionary.  I suggest the following to identify the problem:

1. Open the Resources > Recording Dictionaries area in Producer and see which dictionary is set as default, i.e. the bold one.  If it is a custom dictionary, right click the Simulation dictionary and select Set as Default and try again.  If that fixes the issue, there is something not right with your custom dictionary.  Check the actions language strings for mouse actions and your recording language to see if there is something obvious
2. If you are using the standard recording dictionary and it is unmodified, it may be your Authoring Settings that is the issue.  From experience, I have found that recording can have issues if you modify some values in the Authoring Settings.  For example, modifying the following values in the Authoring Settings can cause recording issues:

 

 

If you have modified your Authoring Settings, please restore the default version of the Authoring Settings in Manager, download the original version of the settings to Producer, and try recording again.

If none of those approaches fixes your issue, please raise a support ticket using Component ID KM-SEN-PRO and get support involved in a more detailed investigation.

Regards
Shane

entry.title: Interfaces IF_EDOC_SOURCE_EXTENSION & IF_EDOC_SOURCE_PROCESS_EXT for DRC in SAP Public Cloud
entry.content:
Objective:

To manually create eDocument for CLM invoices in eDocument Cockpit as itâ€™s not supported, and Relevant indicator is set to false. Therefore, we want to manipulate the Relevant indicator through standard interfaces; IF_EDOC_SOURCE_EXTENSION and IF_EDOC_SOURCE_PROCESS_EXT. These interfaces are provided by SAP in document- Enabling a Source Type for a Process | SAP Help Portal.

Please note that, testing is done in Customizing Demo but actual Customizing system screenshots are just for reference.

Problem:

1) Source Ext. Active checkbox is not available in SSCUI ID 102190 - Activate Source Type Documents for Company Code (pre-requisite 4).

2) Standard class CL_EDOCUMENT which is also used to generate the XML is not released (pre-requisite 1).

3) The extension classes have been created and all pre-requisites for these interfaces, but theyâ€™re not called/triggered (probably bcus of problem 1).

 

Question:

1) Is there a configuration to enable the column â€œSource Ext. Activeâ€?

2) Since itâ€™s a standard object, does this need to be released as well for the extension to work?

3) At which point will the standard process call below methods, or did we miss something?
    a) IF_EDOC_SOURCE_EXTENSION~IS_RELEVANT

    b) IF_EDOC_SOURCE_PROCESS_EXT~ CHECK_RELEVANCE

 

These are all the 4 pre-requisites that are identified based on the documentation.

NOTE: Pre-requisites 1 and 4 are not met due to standard error.

1) The development objects needed to generate XML are already released except for CL_EDOCUMENT which is the standard object.

CL_EDOCUMENT in both Customizing (Actual & Demo) systems are not released yet:

But for custom extension classes for IF_EDOC_SOURCE_EXTENSION & IF_EDOC_SOURCE_PROCESS_EXT they have been set to release:

NOTE: For testing purpose, we maintained both FI_INVOICE, RE_INVOICE & RE_DOC:

2) The source extension class has been implemented for the interface IF_EDOC_SOURCE_EXTENSION:

3) The source process extension class has implemented for the interface IF_EDOC_SOURCE_PROCESS_EXT.

The edoc_Process is MYINV as itâ€™s part of the Customer Invoice.

4) The combination of company code and source type have been set to Active and you've selected the Active and Source Ext. Active:

entry.title: How can the filters of story hyperlinks inserted through text boxes be customized and controlledï¼Ÿ
entry.content:
Dear,

when using SAC Stories - Creating Responsive Pages, I encountered such a business scenario requirement and hope to seek technical solutions or functional support.

Problem description:

Currently, we insert text into the responsive page and link to another Story through the "hyperlink" in the text box. The Story opened by the user through this hyperlink will inherit the default filter values of the form itself (for example, the time filter will display "All Times" by default). However, our business requirement is that when users jump through hyperlinks, the filters of the target Story (such as the time filter) can be automatically set to specific values (for example, only checking "2025") to save users the manual filtering operation steps.

Demand Scenario

1. Current behavior: After the hyperlink jumps, the filters of the target Story use their preset default values (for example, the time filter displays "All Times").

2. Expected behavior: Dynamically control the default values of the filters for the target Story through hyperlink parameters in the responsive page (for example, only select "2025" for the time filter).

Is there a solution? Thank you for your support!

The relevant screenshots are attached.

entry.title: Reinventing Customer Engagement : How SAP Joule Premium CX Shopping Agent Transforms Digital Sales
entry.content:
Introduction

AI agents are powerful tools designed to perform tasks autonomously, effectively mimicking human decision-making processes. Their integration into various business operations and everyday activities is rapidly increasing. So, what defines an AI agent?

AI agents are sophisticated software programs that leverage algorithms, data analysis, and machine learning techniques to carry out tasks that typically demand human intelligence. They are capable of reasoning, learning from experiences, and adapting to new challenges.

AI agents are categorized into several distinct types, including:

  • Chatbots
  • Virtual assistants
  • Recommendation systems
  • Autonomous vehicles And more

Each type has a specific purpose, and together, they significantly enhance efficiency and elevate user experiences.

AI agents have found applications across multiple sectors like Retail, wholesale, healthcare, finance, entertainment and home devices etc.  

SAP's Generative AI Initiatives focus on embedding generative AI across its enterprise solutions to enhance productivity, automation, customer experience and decision-making.

Hereâ€™s a concise overview:

Joule AI Copilot: A core component, Joule is a natural language generative AI assistant integrated into SAPâ€™s portfolio, including SAP S/4HANA, SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Customer Experience (CX), and more.

SAP CX AI Toolkit: Tailored for Customer Experience solutions (e.g., SAP Commerce Cloud, SAP Sales Cloud), this toolkit leverages generative AI for smart product recommendations, dynamic pricing, personalized search, and automated content creation (e.g., product descriptions, marketing emails). It integrates enterprise data with AI models to drive personalization and efficiency.

SAP Business AI: This broader initiative embeds generative AI across SAPâ€™s cloud solutions, including ERP, supply chain, and HR. Key features include:

AI initiative on SAP Customer Experience

The SAP Customer Experience (CX) AI Initiative focuses on integrating advanced artificial intelligence, particularly generative AI, into SAPâ€™s Customer Experience solutions to enhance sales, e-commerce, customer service, and marketing.

SAP CX AI Toolkit: A suite of AI-powered tools that integrates with SAP CX applications (e.g., SAP Commerce Cloud, SAP Sales Cloud) to automate tasks, provide real-time insights, and deliver personalized customer experiences. It leverages enterprise data, proprietary AI models, and large language models (LLMs) for features like smart product recommendations, Customer reviews Sentimental analysis, Visual search and personalized shopping agent  , and automated  product content creation.

Pleaser refer the blog for CX AI toolkit features CX AI in E-Commerce: Transforming Customer Journey... - SAP Community .In this blog, we will explore the shopping agent

The SAP Commerce Cloud CX AI Toolkit Shopping Agent is an artificial intelligence-driven conversational tool aimed at improving the e-commerce experience on the SAP Commerce Cloud platform.

This conversational AI assistant operates as a well-informed digital sales representative, accessible around the clock on your storefront.

By utilizing generative AI and natural language processing, it offers personalized and seamless customer interactions, facilitating product discovery and increasing conversion rates. The shopping agent assists customers in locating the appropriate products through engaging conversations that include relevant pricing information. Additionally, it answers inquiries regarding products, enables product comparisons, allows items to be added to the cart, and provides updates on placed order.

Commerce Prodcut Discovery challenge which are addressed by Shopping Agent 

10% of customers find exactly what theyâ€™re searching for every time

80% of customers leave websites because search didnâ€™t meet expectations

 

 

Traditional commerce gives customer a categories-based search, large number of products to filter manually and fail to provide the granular details of product which they are looking for, making them guess and buy or leave the journey

Using shopping agents, eCommerce customers can meet their key buying journey demands

  • A guiding agent to support their broader mission likeâ€ I need to purchase for this projectâ€
  • The support to help them to reach the product with specific requirements quickly
  • Assisting them in building and completing the shopping mission by suggesting the product set of solution comprise of set of products 
  • Overall, a digital sales associate which helps
    • To have Natural conversation about needs
    • Understands broad scenarios/ Specific requirements
    • Ask questions and get relevant answers about product 
    • Recommends complementary products
    • Compares features & pricing
    • Helping them to finish the purchase and track the same
       

      B2B and B2C Scenarios are handled by Shopping Agent 

B2C Sample Scenarios:

  • A customer asks, â€œCan you recommend a waterproof jacket for under $100?â€ The Shopping Agent responds with tailored recommendations by pulling real-time data from the product catalog and other sources available on Azure Cloud.
  • Customers can also start with broader queries, such as, "Can you suggest some outfits for a summer vacation?" They can ask the Shopping Agent to recommend appropriate sizes, for example, "What size of formal wear would be suitable for someone who is 174 cm tall and weighs 65 kg?"
  • Additionally, customers may inquire about accessories that complement their main outfit, asking, "Can you suggest formal shoes or a handbag that would go well with this dress?"
  • Customers can also ask about the material of a dress, maintenance tips, and suggestions for appropriate occasions to wear specific outfits.

B2B Sample Scenarios:

  • B2B customer inquiry about bulk pricing and compatibility for a specific Model of engineering tool. The agent provides instant answers and suggests related items, streamlining the purchase process
  • B2B customer can ask about the product comparison, volume price options  -Can you compare the motors Sharp PowerE 22i  and  Sharp PowerE 11i?
  • B2B customer can ask about the warranty, annual maintenance terms and contract cost for the engineering tool â€“ â€œSuggest me the annual maintenance contract options for the Troponin Analyzerâ€ or â€œcan you guide me on the installation procedure for Siemens Chemistry AnalyzerA500 ?
  • B2B customers may the compatible accessories for the product â€“ â€œCan you suggest the accessories to setup the Rotary Hammer?â€
  • B2B customers may also ask to order product to cart and check the status of the latest order â€“â€œ Can you add the Switch gear EV550C to cart?â€  or â€œCan you tell me status of my last order?â€
  • B2B customers may ask non product information to the agent - â€œDirect me to FAQ document  or  guide me on payment /refund termsâ€  

Core Capabilities of the SAP CX AI Toolkit Shopping Agent

Shopping agent caters the following three boarder areas.

Specific Requests: I need products with these specific features

Broader Scenarios: I need equipment for this project

Complete Solutions: Help me build a complete solution

 

Digital Service Agent offers the following, 

  • User-friendly configuration interface for creating and customizing self-service agent
  • Ability to easily download and access chat history via the Agent Builder UI
  • Handoff to Support Channel for complex issues or user-requested human assistance, ensuring a smooth transition for effective problem resolution
  • Create a support ticket, complete with a detailed conversation summary, when the agent is unable to resolve the issue
  • AI-powered self-service using product documentation and FAQâ€™s through natural conversation
  • Plug into the digital outlet of your choice such as a Business Portal or e-commerce storefront through a flexible API

Benefits of using shopping agent

Modular: Shopping Agent is modular, powered by combing the one or many of Sug-agents which serves unique purpose, (PriceRecommendationAgent, Add to Cart Agent, Order Status Agent, Self Service Agent). Admin can activate/deactivate the sub-agents during configuration based on the business needs 

Flexibility on utilizing information to guide the customer:  Shopping Agent utilizes the information from the following sources to guide the customer 

  • Commerce product content management (tag, description, attributes, price, media and description) 
  • Product documentation such as installation guides, warranty and Maintenace guides attached as document in PCM or any external sources like Azure Media
  • Any internal (commerce cloud) or external location which serves non product information 
  • Order status and shipping information on order history 
  • Service ticket information from Service Cloud or Commerce Cloud

 Natural Language Interaction:  The Shopping Agent enables customers to engage in natural, conversational queries about products, such as details on features, pricing, availability, or compatibility. It understands complex, multi-part requests, mimicking the expertise of an in-store assistant.

Seamless Integration with SAP Commerce Cloud and external resources like Azure

The Shopping Agent is fully embedded within the SAP ecosystem, allowing it to leverage enterprise data from SAP Commerce Cloud, also connect with external systems like Microsoft Azure Blob Storage for enhanced functionality

Multilingual Support

   The agent supports multiple languages and enables facilitates global customer engagement by generating content in the customerâ€™s preferred language or matching the input language

 Enhanced Product Discovery by incorporating ask the product

 Features like â€œAsk About a Productâ€ allow customers to pose specific questions (e.g., about materials or care instructions) and receive instant responses, improving the shopping experience.

Enterprise-Grade Security

   - The agent ensures data privacy by preventing the storage of customer data in third-party large language models (LLMs) or SAP models. It uses secure data retrieval from SAP CX sources, with features like context grounding and PII (Personally Identifiable Information) obfuscation.

Shopping Agent â€“ Reference Architecture

Shopping Agent Implementation Steps:

 

Shopping Agent â€“ Roadmap

Here the list of roadmap capabilities

  • Ask questions about product availability and the ability to exclude out of stock products from recommendations.
  • Order status includes tracking numbers
  • Automatically recognize product-specific questions on product detail pages. Product pages display clickable, AI-generated questions to start agent conversations
  • Power product recommendations and complementary suggestions using external catalog data
  • Support for Q&A from PDF documents stored as media or classification attributes.

Resources to refer

  • Learning: Utilizing SAP CX AI Toolkit for SAP Commerce Cloud 
  • Doc 
    •  SAP CX AI Toolkit Features | SAP Help Portal 
    • User Guide | SAP Help Portal
  • Webcast: https://gateway.on24.com/wcc/eh/2983783/lp/4635850/master-your-product-catalog-with-business-ai-for-...
  • YouTube: SAP CX AI Toolkit - YouTube 
  • CX AI Toolkit blog: Integrating SAP CX AI Toolkit with SAP Commerce Cl... - SAP Community
  • Source code:   source code is ready to use (composable storefront only) - Open-source code* HERE

 Conclusion

Shopping Agent empowers customers by supporting diverse shopping scenarios, from specific product searches to broader project needs, improving conversion rates, enhancing customer satisfaction, and facilitating a more efficient shopping experience.  Hope the information is useful, if  you like to explore, please reach out to your SAP representative. 

Thank you for your time!
